title: Work to identify 39 migrants found in lorry will ‘take some time’
text:
Detective Chief Inspector Martin Pasmore says he is working closely with Vietnamese ambassador to help identify victims (Picture: PA/Rex)

Police say the 39 migrants found dead in a lorry in Essex had ‘few identification’ documents on them and that work to find out who they are will take some time.

During a press conference this afternoon, Detective Chief Inspector Martin Pasmore said that very few documents were found on the bodies of the victims and that they were using ‘tattoos, marks and scars’ to try to get as much information they could on them.

He said that trying to identify the victims through people from the Vietnamese community in the UK could be a ‘complex scenario’.

He said: ‘It may well be that there are people watching this tonight that are thinking “I’m here in the UK and I’m here illegally and I want to come forward, I want to obviously try and identify my loved ones and be reunited”, but they are frightened to come forward.’

He explained he had met with a ‘facilitator’ of one of the websites run for the Vietnamese community to help build trust between it and the police.

The inspector added that he hoped it would help encourage people to ‘take that leap of faith’ and make contact with Essex police.

Police are seen at the scene where bodies were discovered in a lorry container, in Grays, Essex (Picture: Reuters)

Detective Chief Inspector Martin Pasmore says (Picture: PA)

Vietnamese woman Pham Thi Tra is feared to be among the victims

Nguyen Dinh Luong has been named by relatives as a possible victim in the Essex lorry deaths (Picture: BBC)

He said: ‘If you come in to us, we will do everything we can to put our arm around you, take you through this process, identify as quickly as possible to see whether or not we do indeed have one of your loved ones involved in this tragic incident.’

DCI Martin Pasmore also said he had met with the Vietnamese ambassador on Saturday morning as part of efforts to engage with the country’s wider community.

He said: ‘Although we can’t speculate at this time on the nationality of our victims, it’s clear from everybody that we are getting a large amount of engagement from the Vietnamese population, from communities home and abroad.’

He added: ‘What I’ve done this morning, is I’ve met with the Vietnamese ambassador and we are building a really good and rapid rapport.’

DCI Pasmore said the ambassador had visited and paid tribute at the civic centre in Grays.
